scenarioDescription:
The HD 23079 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 23079 is a star with 1.12 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.07 times its radius. It is located 109.13 light years away from the solar system.

HD 23079 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 23079 system


HD 23079 b

HD 23079 b was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory, in 2002-05, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.60 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 23079 b is 829.980 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 23079 b is 13.200 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 23079 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 23079, which contains 1 exoplanets and was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope.
name: HD 23079 - System With 1 Exoplanet
